questions.answerA: Opening the door and signaling for the students to approach.
questions.answerB: Turning on the alternating red lights.
questions.answerC: Pulling over to the side of the road.
questions.explanation: When stopping to pick up students, a school bus driver should ensure that all surrounding traffic has stopped before opening the door and signaling for the students to approach the bus.

questions.question: When approaching a school bus stop, the driver should:
questions.answerC: Talk to students on the bus.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should always approach bus stops slowly and cautiously.

questions.question: Before a bus enters a curve, the driver should:
questions.explanation: Buses should always enter curves at reduced speeds. A driver should be especially cautious if entering a curve under wet or slippery conditions.

questions.question: The standee line:
questions.answerA: Is a line that passengers should not cross.
questions.answerB: Is a line upon which passengers should stand.
questions.answerC: Is a line that should be used as passengers exit the bus.
questions.explanation: On a bus designed to carry standing passengers, no passengers may stand in front of the rear of the driver's seat. Any such bus must have a line on the floor, or some other marking, that indicates where passengers may not stand. This is called a standee line.

questions.question: Roof hatches on buses:
questions.answerB: Must always be closed when driving.
questions.answerC: May be locked in a partially-opened position.
questions.explanation: On a bus, it is acceptable to lock some roof hatches in a partially-opened position to provide fresh air, but this should not be made a regular practice. Remember that opening these hatches will slightly increase a bus's clearance.

questions.question: When students are being picked up by a school bus:
questions.answerA: The students should wait at a designated bus stop.
questions.answerB: The driver should stop to pick up students who are walking to a designated bus stop.
questions.answerC: The parents may choose where the bus stops are located.
questions.explanation: School bus drivers may only pick up students at official stops designated by authorized school officials.

questions.question: ABS allows you to:
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) help prevent brake lockup when driving on slippery surfaces. If a driver brakes too hard on a slippery surface, ABS makes it easier for the driver to maintain control of their vehicle. A vehicle equipped with ABS should be driven and braked in the same way as a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you should:
questions.explanation: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you must make sure everything is safe and in proper working condition. Take the time to ensure that each handhold and railing is securely in place and safe to be used.

questions.question: A school bus's danger zones are located:
questions.answerA: Only to the front of the bus.
questions.answerB: Only to the rear and left side of the bus.
questions.answerC: To the front, sides, and rear of the bus.
questions.explanation: The danger zones of a school bus are areas in which children are most likely to be hit, either by another vehicle or by the bus itself. Such areas are located to the front, sides, and rear of a bus. Danger zones can extend 10 feet from every side of a bus.

questions.question: To safely unload a bus, students should:
questions.answerA: Remain seated until they are told to exit.
questions.answerB: Stand up and head toward the door while the bus is slowing down.
questions.answerC: Exit the bus and stand directly next to the bus while it is being driven away from the stop.
questions.explanation: Students who are about to unload a school bus should remain seated until the driver tells them that it is safe to exit. After exiting the bus, they should walk to a position that is at least 10 feet away from the bus so the driver can clearly see them.

questions.question: Backing a school bus is:
questions.answerC: Only to be done in the morning.
questions.explanation: Backing a school bus is strongly discouraged and should only be done if there is no safe alternative. If you must drive in reverse, be sure to follow all proper safety protocol.

questions.question: As students exit a school bus, the driver should watch to ensure that they:
questions.answerB: Do not get caught on the handrail or door.
questions.explanation: It is possible for students to be injured, or even killed, as a result of their clothing, accessories, or bodies getting caught on a handrail or door while exiting a school bus. The driver should closely watch students as they exit to ensure that they have all unloaded the bus successfully and have reached a safe location.

questions.question: Crossover mirrors help the driver see:
questions.answerC: The left side of the bus.
questions.explanation: Crossover mirrors are used to help a driver see the danger zone area directly in front of a school bus. The mirrors should also display the danger zone areas to the left and right sides of the bus, including the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: If you come to railroad tracks while driving a school bus, you should generally:
questions.answerA: Check the tracks, but continue driving without stopping.
questions.answerB: Stop 15 to 50 feet before the nearest rail.
questions.answerC: Stop 75 feet before the nearest rail.
questions.explanation: In general, school bus drivers should stop before any railroad crossings to check the tracks for approaching trains. Drivers should stop no closer than 15 feet and no farther than 50 feet from the nearest rail in order to have the best view of the tracks. They should look and listen for approaching trains before proceeding through the crossing.

questions.question: Crossover mirrors help the driver see:
questions.answerC: The left side of the bus.
questions.explanation: Crossover mirrors are used to help a driver see the danger zone area directly in front of a school bus. The mirrors should also display the danger zone areas to the left and right sides of the bus, including the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: Fueling a bus while passengers are on board is:
questions.answerB: Acceptable only on trips of more than 100 miles.
questions.answerC: Acceptable only if doing so is unavoidable.
questions.explanation: A bus should not be refueled while passengers are on board unless it is absolutely necessary to do so. In particular, a bus with riders on board should never be refueled inside an enclosed building.

questions.question: When stopped at a railroad crossing, one way for a bus driver to hear if a train is approaching is by:
questions.answerC: Waiting for the passengers on the bus to quiet down on their own.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing, buses should stop between 15 and 50 feet from the nearest track and the driver should look both ways for a train. They should open the forward door if it improves their ability to see or hear an oncoming train.

questions.question: When driving a school bus, mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.explanation: You should always check the adjustment of all your mirrors before operating a school bus.

questions.question: If a student is believed to have suffered a back injury, you should:
questions.answerC: Encourage them to try to stand.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should not attempt to move a student who has suffered a neck or spinal injury unless the student's life is in immediate danger.

questions.question: The inside rearview mirror is used to:
questions.answerB: See potential hazards on the road.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.explanation: The overhead inside rearview mirror in a school bus is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: The overhead inside rearview mirror should be positioned to show:
questions.answerB: All of the students on the bus.
questions.explanation: The top portion of the overhead inside rearview mirror should be positioned to display the top of the bus's rear window. This mirror positioning should allow the driver to see all of the students on the bus, including the heads of the students sitting immediately behind the driver.

questions.question: When dropping off students at a school, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Secure the bus by turning off the engine.
questions.answerB: Leave the key in the ignition, if leaving the driver’s compartment.
questions.answerC: Read a book while students unload.
questions.explanation: When unloading students at a school, a bus driver must secure the bus by turning off the engine. If they must leave the driver's compartment, they should remove the key from the ignition. The driver must supervise the unloading process.

questions.question: Emergency roof hatches on a bus:
questions.answerA: Must be closed before the bus is driven.
questions.answerB: Can be opened to allow for air movement during a drive.
questions.answerC: Must be removed before the bus is driven.
questions.explanation: On a bus, it is permissible to lock some emergency roof hatches in an open position to allow in fresh air. However, this should not be a regular practice.

questions.question: If you must drive in reverse at a student pick-up point, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up before the students board the bus.
questions.answerB: Back up after the students board the bus.
questions.answerC: Back up while students direct you.
questions.explanation: Backing in a school bus is strongly discouraged and should be done only if there is no other safe way to move the vehicle. If you must drive in reverse at a student pick-up point, you should wait until all students have first loaded the bus.

questions.question: Backing a school bus is:
questions.answerC: Only to be done in the morning.
questions.explanation: Backing a school bus is strongly discouraged and should only be done if there is no safe alternative. If you must drive in reverse, be sure to follow all proper safety protocol.

questions.question: A posted speed limit for cars:
questions.answerB: May be too fast for buses.
questions.answerC: May be too slow for buses.
questions.explanation: Particularly on curves, the maximum posted speed limit may be safe to be driven in a car but too fast to be driven in a bus. Be especially careful when the road has been made slippery by rain or snow.

questions.question: Students loading and unloading a bus:
questions.answerA: Is simple and does not need to be supervised.
questions.answerB: Can be dangerous and should be supervised.
questions.answerC: May be done without the bus driver present.
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year during loading or unloading of school buses than while riding on school buses. Therefore, it is critical that school bus drivers follow appropriate safety procedures during loading and unloading. This process should never take place without being properly supervised.

questions.question: While passengers are on board a bus, refueling the bus in an enclosed space, allowing the bus to be towed, and conversing with the passengers are considered to be:
questions.explanation: Bus drivers should not engage in conversation with passengers, fuel a bus inside an enclosed building, or tow or push a disabled bus with riders aboard the vehicle. These are all considered to be prohibited practices.

questions.question: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you should:
questions.explanation: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you must make sure everything is safe and in proper working condition. Take the time to ensure that each handhold and railing is securely in place and safe to be used.

questions.question: Adjust a bus's mirrors:
questions.answerC: At the first stoplight after starting your shift.
questions.explanation: The adjustment of mirrors should be checked prior to the start of any trip.

questions.question: When approaching a school bus stop, the bus driver should:
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should always approach bus stops slowly and cautiously.

questions.question: Properly adjusted crossover mirrors allow you to see all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: The right and left front tires touching the ground.
questions.answerB: The area in front of the bus.
questions.answerC: The tops of the right and left rear tires.
questions.explanation: Properly adjusted crossover mirrors on a school bus should allow the driver to see the entire area in front of the bus, from the front bumper at ground level to a point where direct vision is possible. The mirrors should also display the right and left front tires touching the ground, as well as the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: ABS helps you:
questions.answerB: Keep your wheels from locking up.
questions.answerC: Count the number of students boarding the bus.
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up when the driver brakes hard on a slippery surface.

questions.question: The standee line:
questions.answerA: Is a line that passengers should not cross.
questions.answerB: Is a line upon which passengers should stand.
questions.answerC: Is a line that should be used as passengers exit the bus.
questions.explanation: On a bus designed to carry standing passengers, no passengers may stand in front of the rear of the driver's seat. Any such bus must have a line on the floor, or some other marking, that indicates where passengers may not stand. This is called a standee line.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, the best way to learn about transporting hazardous materials is to:
questions.explanation: While the manual includes all of the information required to pass the hazardous materials knowledge test, you should consider reading the manual as only the first step to learning about the topic. You can learn more by reading and understanding the federal and state rules about the transportation of hazardous materials, as well as by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: If transporting hazardous materials, a shipper should warn others by:
questions.answerA: Posting HazMat placards on their truck.
questions.answerB: Putting flashing lights on their truck.
questions.explanation: Shippers of certain kinds of hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs, known as placards, on any transporting vehicles. Shippers are required to provide applicable placards, labels, shipping papers, and emergency response information.

questions.question: A placard should be placed:
questions.answerA: At least three inches away from any other markings.
questions.answerB: Under a ladder, if space is an issue.
questions.answerC: On a background that is a similar color to the placard.
questions.explanation: A placard must be placed at least three inches away from any other markings. The placard should be kept clear of attachments or devices, such as doors and ladders. Placards should always be placed against a background of a contrasting color.

questions.question: When trying to control a minor truck fire, what should you do before opening trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. Leave the doors closed if there is a cargo fire.

questions.question: The only way to effectively check your tire pressure is:
questions.answerC: By pushing on the tire to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: If "Inhalation Hazard" appears on a shipping paper, the shipper should provide which placard?
questions.answerB: Poison Gas or Poison Inhalation Hazard
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on the shipping paper or package, you must display the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" or "Poison Gas" placards, as appropriate.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials may need to be:
questions.answerB: Circled by a pen or marker.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be distinguished in one of three ways. They must be entered first on the shipping paper, highlighted in a contrasting color, or properly marked with an "X" in a column titled "HM."

questions.question: If you identify hazardous materials leaking while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving to find a phone booth and call the National Response Center.
questions.answerC: Leave the area to find help.
questions.explanation: If you discover that a cargo of hazardous materials is leaking from your vehicle, you should park the vehicle as soon as possible. The longer you continue driving, the longer the trail of contamination becomes. While this creates potential danger and harm to others, it also increases clean-up expenses.

questions.question: Placards showing the type of hazardous materials in a vehicle are usually which shape?
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.explanation: On a compressed gas tank, liquid discharge valves must always be kept closed, except during loading and unloading.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you may park no closer than ____ from the nearest building.
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you should not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building, unless you are parking for a short period of time while performing an operational necessity, like refueling.

questions.question: When Division 1.3 materials are being transported, the floor liner should be:
questions.explanation: You should use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors must be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are any metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: You may leave a vehicle that is carrying explosives unattended:
questions.answerC: On the shoulder of a highway.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.explanation: You should not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded cargo tank used to transport materials that are categorized as Class 3 (flammable liquids) or Division 2.1 (gases). Do not smoke or carry a lit cigar, pipe, or cigarette near a vehicle containing flammable or explosive materials.

questions.question: When loading containers of hazardous materials, you should not use:
questions.explanation: Always protect containers of hazardous materials. When loading hazardous materials, never use equipment that could damage containers or packaging, such as hooks.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking but the driver does not have access to a phone, they should:
questions.answerA: Drive to a phone to alert emergency personnel.
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean-up facility.
questions.explanation: If a cargo of hazardous materials begins to leak, do not move your vehicle any more than safety requires. If you continue to drive, an even larger area will become contaminated. Instead, you should park your vehicle, secure it, stay with the vehicle, and contact the proper emergency personnel. If you do not have access to a phone, you should send someone else to get help.

questions.question: In general, before loading or unloading any flammable liquids, an engine should be:
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump. Ground the tank before opening the filling hole and maintain the ground until after closing the filling hole.

questions.question: When refueling a vehicle carrying hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The engine should be left on.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The gas nozzle may be left unattended.
questions.explanation: If you need to refuel a vehicle carrying hazardous materials, you must first turn off the engine. While refueling, someone must be at the nozzle and controlling the fuel flow at all times.

questions.question: Which type of material may be required to have a transport index?
questions.explanation: Some radioactive materials are required to be accompanied by a transport index. A transport index is a number that indicates how much control the material will require during transport. The total transport index of all cargo in a single vehicle may not exceed 50.

questions.question: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a background check through which agency?
questions.explanation: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a federal security threat assessment done by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: An indicator that cargo contains hazardous materials is:
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged in cardboard boxes.
questions.explanation: Packaging can be an indicator of whether or not materials are hazardous. Cylinders and drums are often used to hold and transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: If transporting explosives:
questions.answerA: You must have a written route plan.
questions.answerB: You should take the shortest possible route.
questions.explanation: If transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you must follow a written route plan. Whenever placarded, avoid heavily populated areas, crowds, tunnels, narrow streets, and alleys. Be sure to research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.explanation: Containers of hazardous materials should be braced so they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation.

questions.question: How many identical placards must be placed on a vehicle?
questions.explanation: A placarded vehicle must have at least four identical placards: one on the front, one on the rear, and one on each side of the vehicle.

questions.question: If you notice a cargo leak, you should identify the leaking hazardous materials by:
questions.explanation: If you discover a cargo leak while transporting hazardous materials, use the shipping papers, label, or package location to identify which materials are involved. Do not try to touch or smell the leaking materials to determine what they are because doing so could result in injury or death.

questions.question: A material’s hazard class reflects:
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material.
questions.answerB: How quickly the material must reach its destination.
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will be placed into one of nine classes to explain the type of risks associated with the material.

questions.question: Shipping papers must include:
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to include an emergency response telephone number on shipping papers.

questions.question: A clue that your shipment contains hazardous materials is that:
questions.answerA: The shipper is in the business of firework or munition dealing.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that involves such materials. Examples include paint dealers; chemical suppliers; scientific supply houses; pest control businesses; agricultural supply firms; and dealers in explosives, munitions, or fireworks.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you must park at least ____ from any building.
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, do not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building; a place where people gather; or an open fire.

questions.question: Who must mark and label the materials for shipping?
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to warn drivers and others about the risks of the materials by putting hazard warning labels on packages, putting placards on the transporting vehicles, and providing proper shipping papers and emergency response information.

questions.question: To transport hazardous materials, a driver needs:
questions.answerB: A CDL with hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a tank endorsement.
questions.explanation: To drive a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, you must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.explanation: Containers of hazardous materials should be braced so they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation.

questions.question: When trying to control a minor truck fire, what should you do before opening trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. Leave the doors closed if there is a cargo fire.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing while transporting chlorine:
questions.answerA: You must stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerB: You must reduce your speed before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: You may proceed across the tracks without stopping if no warning lights are flashing.
questions.explanation: If transporting any amount of chlorine, a driver must always stop at a railroad crossing 15 to 50 feet from the nearest track, regardless of the presence of a train.

questions.question: Load hazardous materials:
questions.explanation: Always load hazardous materials away from heat sources. Be aware of regulations on explosive or flammable materials that prohibit them from being loaded in cargo spaces with heaters.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.explanation: On a compressed gas tank, liquid discharge valves must always be kept closed, except during loading and unloading.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.explanation: You should not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded cargo tank used to transport materials that are categorized as Class 3 (flammable liquids) or Division 2.1 (gases). Do not smoke or carry a lit cigar, pipe, or cigarette near a vehicle containing flammable or explosive materials.

questions.question: Shipping papers should be:
questions.answerC: Easily seen by anyone entering the cab.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: You may leave a vehicle that is carrying explosives unattended:
questions.answerC: On the shoulder of a highway.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: When loading containers of hazardous materials, you should not use:
questions.explanation: Always protect containers of hazardous materials. When loading hazardous materials, never use equipment that could damage containers or packaging, such as hooks.

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the box must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Packages that contain liquid containers must have orientation markers. Arrows displayed on the box should be pointing in the correct upright direction.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle may be:
questions.answerB: Either awake or asleep inside the vehicle.
questions.explanation: A person attending a parked placarded vehicle must be either awake inside the vehicle or they must be within 100 feet of it. If not inside the vehicle itself, the person must have a clear view of the vehicle. The person attending may not be inside the sleeper berth.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 materials should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gases), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids), the use of heaters in the same space is generally prohibited.

questions.question: If transporting hazardous materials, a shipper should warn others by:
questions.answerA: Posting HazMat placards on their truck.
questions.answerB: Putting flashing lights on their truck.
questions.explanation: Shippers of certain kinds of hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs, known as placards, on any transporting vehicles. Shippers are required to provide applicable placards, labels, shipping papers, and emergency response information.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you must park at least ____ from any building.
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, do not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building; a place where people gather; or an open fire.

questions.question: Which type of material may be required to have a transport index?
questions.explanation: Some radioactive materials are required to be accompanied by a transport index. A transport index is a number that indicates how much control the material will require during transport. The total transport index of all cargo in a single vehicle may not exceed 50.

questions.question: If you are transporting hazardous materials and the cargo is on fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to put it out with a fire extinguisher.
questions.answerB: Contact emergency personnel and let them battle the fire.
questions.answerC: Hope the fire goes out by itself.
questions.explanation: Fighting a hazardous materials fire requires special training and protective gear. Unless you have the proper equipment and training, do not try to fight a hazardous materials fire yourself.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials. They must supply the warning placards.

questions.question: Many products classed as poison are also:
questions.explanation: Many hazardous materials classified as poisonous are also flammable.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers may not be kept:
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s door.
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door.
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened.
questions.explanation: Shipping papers must be quickly accessible in the event of an emergency. While driving, operators must keep the papers in a pouch on the driver’s door or in clear view and within immediate reach while their seat belt is fastened. Shipping papers may be kept on the driver’s seat when the driver is out of the vehicle.

questions.question: The National Response Center must be notified of an incident resulting in any of the following, except:
questions.explanation: The National Response Center must be notified of any incident that results in death; hospitalization; $50,000 or more in estimated property damage; an evacuation of the general public or closure of a major transportation route/facility for more then one hour; fire, breakage, spillage, or suspected contamination involving radiation, bacteria, or toxins. Additionally, if the carrier judges the situation to be so serious that it should be reported, it should be reported.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be:
questions.answerA: Inside a gas station looking through a window.
questions.answerB: In the vehicle, awake or asleep.
questions.explanation: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be awake inside the vehicle or otherwise within 100 feet of the vehicle; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: Which agency helps coordinate emergency response to chemical hazards?
questions.answerC: The United Center for Chemical Assistance
questions.explanation: The National Response Center helps coordinate emergency response to chemical hazards. It should be contacted in the event of a hazardous materials spill.

questions.question: An indicator that cargo contains hazardous materials is:
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged in cardboard boxes.
questions.explanation: Packaging can be an indicator of whether or not materials are hazardous. Cylinders and drums are often used to hold and transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: While driving, shipping papers should be:
questions.explanation: While hazardous materials are being transported, shipping papers should either be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be clearly visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: Placards showing the type of hazardous materials in a vehicle are usually which shape?
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: If your engine runs a pump used during delivery of compressed gas, you should turn off the engine:
questions.explanation: Unless your engine runs a pump for product transfer, turn it off when loading or unloading a compressed gas tank. If you do use your engine to run a pump, you should turn the engine off after the product transfer but before unhooking the hoses.

questions.question: A hazardous material's identification number should appear:
questions.answerC: On a sticker near the material's shipping container.
questions.explanation: A material's ID number must appear on its accompanying shipping paper as well as on its packaging. It also must appear on cargo tanks and other bulk packaging.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you may park no closer than ____ from the nearest building.
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you should not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building, unless you are parking for a short period of time while performing an operational necessity, like refueling.

questions.question: Who must mark and label the materials for shipping?
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to warn drivers and others about the risks of the materials by putting hazard warning labels on packages, putting placards on the transporting vehicles, and providing proper shipping papers and emergency response information.

questions.question: Alcohol can be removed from your system:
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate, so the only way to sober up after consuming alcohol is to allow your body time to remove the alcohol on its own.

questions.question: Operating combination vehicles usually requires ­­­­­____ operating single vehicles.
questions.answerB: About the same level of skill as
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles are usually heavier and longer than single combination vehicles. Operating a combination vehicle requires a higher level of driving skill than operating a single commercial vehicle.

questions.question: If you must drive in reverse, using driver's side backing:
questions.answerC: Is only recommended if it is raining.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, it is safest to back toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This way, as the driver, you will have the best possible view of your path of travel.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep grade, you switch into a lower gear:
questions.answerB: When you have already started the grade.
questions.answerC: As far down the grade as possible.
questions.explanation: You should shift your vehicle's transmission into a low gear before staring a downhill grade. Be prepared for gravity to increase your vehicle's speed when traveling downhill.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, turning toward the driver’s side is encouraged because:
questions.answerA: The driver will have the best possible view.
questions.answerB: Power lines should be on the passenger's side.
questions.answerC: Other drivers can offer assistance on the passenger's side.
questions.explanation: When driving in reverse, it is always recommended that a driver backs their vehicle toward its left side. This will allow the driver the best possible view of the rear of their vehicle.

questions.question: If approaching a vehicle with a distracted driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Maintain a safe distance from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you see a distracted driver, give them plenty of space and maintain a safe following distance.

questions.question: Dual tires should:
questions.answerA: Always come into contact with one another.
questions.answerB: Come into contact with one another fairly regularly.
questions.answerC: Not come into contact with one another.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle, you should verify that your dual tires do not come into contact with one another, or with any other part of the vehicle.

questions.question: You can confirm that a tractor protection valve is working properly by:
questions.answerB: Opening all of the vehicle's shut-off valves.
questions.answerC: Releasing air with the brake pedal and waiting for the emergency signal to activate.
questions.explanation: You should test the tractor protection valve by allowing the air supply to properly charge, turning off the engine, then releasing air from the system by pressing the brake pedal several times. The tractor protection valve should move into its emergency position when psi drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997, and other vehicles with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1998, must be equipped with anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: You should check and adjust your mirrors:
questions.explanation: Be sure to check your mirrors before beginning a drive. Your posture may change day to day and your mirrors may need to be adjusted.

questions.question: To stay alert while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Eat a heavy meal before beginning your trip.
questions.answerC: Ride with a second person who can share driving responsibilities.
questions.explanation: Splitting driving responsibilities with a second driver lowers the chance that either of you will drive while fatigued. You can also reduce the risk of fatigue by avoiding heavy foods and keeping the interior of the cab cool.

questions.question: To prevent your vehicle from rolling backward when beginning to move, you can:
questions.answerA: Partly engage the clutch before taking your foot off the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Place the vehicle in second gear.
questions.answerC: Use the parking brake when stopping.
questions.explanation: To ensure that your vehicle does not roll backward when beginning to move after a stop, you should partly engage the clutch before removing your right foot from the brake pedal.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving, but have the brakes repaired within a week.
questions.answerB: Pull over and inspect the brakes.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should immediately bring the vehicle to a safe stop while you are still able to control the brakes. Inspect and repair the brakes as soon as possible.

questions.question: When making a left turn, you should start the turn:
questions.answerA: Before reaching the center of the intersection.
questions.answerB: No sooner than the center of the intersection.
questions.answerC: After your rear wheels have passed the center of the intersection.
questions.explanation: When making a left turn, you should wait until you reach the center of the intersection before actually beginning to turn. Due to off-tracking, the left side of your vehicle could hit another driver if you begin turning too early.

questions.question: The “crack-the-whip” effect for doubles and triples is:
questions.answerB: Only a problem when it's raining.
questions.explanation: Double and triple trailer combinations are more likely to be overturned due to the "crack-the-whip" effect than are other vehicles. Drivers must steer gently when pulling trailers.

questions.question: A distracted driver:
questions.answerA: Usually follows the rules of the road.
questions.answerC: Is a good person to follow.
questions.explanation: Distracted drivers perceive hazards on the road more slowly than drivers who are focused, or they do not perceive hazards at all.

questions.question: When braking with ABS, you should:
questions.answerC: Brake harder than you would with a different braking system.
questions.explanation: When braking a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should not brake any differently than you would if driving a vehicle with a different braking system.

questions.question: A thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces is called:
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet. You should be very careful when temperatures are below freezing and the road looks wet.

questions.question: A cargo van is:
questions.answerA: Usually the same height with or without a load.
questions.answerB: Usually taller with a heavy load than with a light load.
questions.answerC: Usually shorter with a heavy load than with a light load.
questions.explanation: The added weight of a heavy load will make a vehicle sit lower than usual. A vehicle will often be taller when carrying a light load than when carrying a heavy load. If your vehicle fits under an overpass while carrying a full load, it is not guaranteed that it will fit under the same overpass if it is empty.

questions.question: Radial and bias-ply tires:
questions.answerB: Should be used together on the front of a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Radial and bias-ply tires should not be used together. All wheels on a vehicle should be the same style and equally-sized.

questions.question: Look into the back of the fifth wheel:
questions.answerB: If your vehicle begins to skid.
questions.explanation: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and look into the back of the fifth wheel. Ensure that the fifth wheel jaws are secured around the shank of the kingpin.

questions.question: What does the vehicle inspection report do?
questions.answerA: Inform the motor carrier about problems that may need fixing
questions.answerB: Ensure that the vehicle is inspected regularly
questions.answerC: Keep people accountable for inspecting the vehicle
questions.explanation: A vehicle inspection report keeps the carrier informed about any problems that need to be fixed.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerA: Explain why you must check the items you are checking.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: Older trailers are not equipped with spring brakes. This means that if the air supply for a vehicle's air braking system leaks away:
questions.answerB: The trailer will not have brakes.
questions.explanation: Older trailers do not have spring brakes. This means that if the air supply in an older trailer's air tank has leaked away, there will be no working brakes connected to the trailer and its wheels will turn freely.

questions.question: Do not base your decision to shift gears on:
questions.answerC: The actions of the vehicle next to you.
questions.explanation: One way to know when it is time to shift gears is to learn your vehicle's operating rpm range. You should shift up when your engine reaches the top of that range. You can also learn which speeds each gear is good for and shift up based on your speedometer.

questions.question: A Class 1 hazardous material is:
questions.explanation: Explosives are placed in hazardous materials Class 1.

questions.question: Routine vehicle inspections should be done to ensure:
questions.explanation: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle is to ensure the safety of yourself and other road users.

questions.question: Radial and bias-ply tires:
questions.answerB: Should be used together on the front of a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Radial and bias-ply tires should not be used together. All wheels on a vehicle should be the same style and equally-sized.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of fatigue?
questions.explanation: Potential warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing, frequent blinking, or heavy eyelids; yawning repeatedly or rubbing your eyes; daydreaming; wandering or disconnected thoughts; trouble remembering the last few miles you've driven; missing exits or traffic signs; having trouble keeping your head up; drifting from your lane; following too closely; hitting a shoulder rumble strip; or feeling restless and irritable.

questions.question: What do the two systems of a dual air brake system share?
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull over and figure out what's wrong.
questions.explanation: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should stop driving as soon as possible and try to figure out what is wrong. There could be an issue in your vehicle that could lead to engine failure and possibly a fire.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerA: Explain what you would inspect and why.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be required to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. During this inspection, you must explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why you are inspecting those items.

questions.question: By beginning a left turn before reaching the center of an intersection, you:
questions.answerA: Will likely complete the turn satisfactorily.
questions.answerB: May hit other vehicles with the left side of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Can expect other drivers to move their vehicles to accommodate your turn.
questions.explanation: When planning to turn left at an intersection, make sure you have reached the center of the intersection before beginning the turn. If you turn too soon, off-tracking may cause the left side of your vehicle to hit another vehicle.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, a separate air tank can be used:
questions.answerA: To make the air brakes work more effectively.
questions.answerB: To temporarily release the spring brakes.
questions.answerC: To charge the brakes on the rear trailer.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: What is road rage?
questions.answerA: Operating a motor vehicle with the intent of doing harm to others
questions.answerB: Operating a motor vehicle that is deemed unsafe
questions.answerC: Operating a motor vehicle that has not been inspected
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is defined as operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner. Road rage is defined as operating a motor vehicle with the intent of doing harm to others, or the intent of physically assaulting another driver or their vehicle.

questions.question: When driving at night, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Make sure your glasses are clean.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you can see as well as possible, don't wear sunglasses when driving at night. If you wear eyeglasses, make sure they are clean and unscratched. Make sure you are rested and alert before driving at night.

questions.question: When entering traffic while operating a double or triple, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume other drivers will make enough space for their vehicle to safely merge into traffic.
questions.answerB: Wait for a gap that is large enough for their entire vehicle to safely merge into traffic.
questions.explanation: Doubles and triples take up more space than other commercial vehicles. Before entering or crossing traffic while driving a double or triple, be sure there is a space large enough for your entire vehicle to operate without causing any collisions.

questions.question: Regrooved tires are:
questions.answerA: Allowed only on the front of a bus.
questions.answerB: Allowed only on the rear of a bus.
questions.answerC: Not allowed anywhere on a bus.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are not permitted to be used on the front of a bus.

questions.question: A steering wheel should be:
questions.answerA: Held with one hand while the other hand rests.
questions.answerB: Held with both hands to ensure an adequate grip.
questions.answerC: Released if the vehicle is approaching a bump.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should be held firmly with each hand on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: You should check and adjust your mirrors:
questions.explanation: Be sure to check your mirrors before beginning a drive. Your posture may change day to day and your mirrors may need to be adjusted.

questions.question: The rods in S-cam brakes move the slack adjusters when air pressure is added to the brake chambers. This air pressure is added to the chambers when the driver:
questions.explanation: When pressing the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air will enter the brake chambers. The added air pressure will push out the rods and move slack adjusters, twisting the brake camshafts.

questions.question: If unable to tell if the road is becoming icy and slippery, a driver:
questions.answerB: May open their window and feel the front of the side mirror for ice.
questions.answerC: Should look at the road closely.
questions.explanation: If you think the road surface may be becoming icy but you are not certain, you can open your window and feel the front of the side mirror, mirror support, or antenna. If ice has formed on any of these items, the road is likely becoming icy as well.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Cannot be used on vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can help drivers see a larger area.
questions.explanation: Many large vehicles have curved, convex mirrors. Convex mirrors allow drivers to see a wider area than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they really are.

questions.question: If you notice a cargo leak, you should identify the leaking hazardous materials by:
questions.explanation: If you discover a cargo leak while transporting hazardous materials, use the shipping papers, label, or package location to identify which materials are involved. Do not try to touch or smell the leaking materials to determine what they are because doing so could result in injury or death.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in an air brake system is releasing air:
questions.answerA: You should not be concerned as this is a normal process.
questions.answerB: There is something wrong with the brakes.
questions.explanation: The safety relief valve in an air brake system releases air if necessary to prevent pressure in the system from becoming too high. If the valve starts releasing air, there is something wrong. Have a mechanic fix the problem.

questions.question: The radiator cap:
questions.answerA: Should not be removed when the coolant is hot.
questions.answerB: Can be removed when the coolant is hot.
questions.answerC: Should be cool to the touch under normal driving conditions.
questions.explanation: Never remove the radiator cap or any part of the pressurized cooling system until it has cooled. Opening the cap while the system is too hot could release steam and boiling water that could severely burn you. If the radiator cap is cool to the touch, the system is likely cool enough for you to open the cap.

questions.question: After two violations of any state law regarding hand-held mobile phone use:
questions.answerA: You will need to cancel your mobile phone service.
questions.answerC: You will be required to drive 10 mph under the posted speed limit for a period of time.
questions.explanation: If you are twice convicted of violating any state law regarding hand-held mobile phone use, your CDL will be disqualified. Consequences will become more severe with subsequent violations.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, turning toward the driver’s side is encouraged because:
questions.answerA: The driver will have the best possible view.
questions.answerB: Power lines should be on the passenger's side.
questions.answerC: Other drivers can offer assistance on the passenger's side.
questions.explanation: When driving in reverse, it is always recommended that a driver backs their vehicle toward its left side. This will allow the driver the best possible view of the rear of their vehicle.

questions.question: What does an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) do?
questions.answerA: It allows a vehicle's wheels to lock up.
questions.answerB: It prevents a vehicle's wheels from locking up.
questions.answerC: It makes turning a vehicle easier.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. If ABS detects impending lockup, it reduces braking pressure to a safe level.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be:
questions.answerA: Inside a gas station looking through a window.
questions.answerB: In the vehicle, awake or asleep.
questions.explanation: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be awake inside the vehicle or otherwise within 100 feet of the vehicle; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: How can a driver maintain alertness while driving?
questions.explanation: Eating heavy foods before driving or keeping the temperature in a cab too high can cause a driver to become drowsy while behind the wheel. Exercising and maintaining a healthy diet will help a driver to stay alert while driving.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve:
questions.answerA: Should always be used for parking.
questions.answerB: Should only be used for parking on a downgrade.
questions.answerC: Should never be used for parking.
questions.explanation: Never use the trailer hand valve while parking because doing so may release the air pressure  from the braking system, releasing the brakes that are holding the vehicle in place. Instead, use the parking brake or wheel chocks.

questions.question: Trailers built before ____ are not required to have spring brakes.
questions.explanation: Trailers built before 1975 are not required to have spring brakes. When parking a trailer without spring brakes, be sure to use wheel chocks to prevent the trailer from rolling.

questions.question: If a vehicle is power steering-equipped, the hoses should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, you should inspect the hoses, pumps, and fluid levels. Specifically check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: What should you do if your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks?
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle and call for assistance.
questions.answerC: Continue trying to get your vehicle off the tracks until you are successful.
questions.explanation: If your CMV gets stuck on railroad tracks, you should immediately leave the vehicle and get away from the tracks. Check the signposts or signal housing at the crossing for emergency contact information and call 911, or another appropriate emergency number.

questions.question: When driving at night, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Make sure your glasses are clean.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you can see as well as possible, don't wear sunglasses when driving at night. If you wear eyeglasses, make sure they are clean and unscratched. Make sure you are rested and alert before driving at night.

questions.question: Carrying gases or liquids in a leaking tank is:
questions.explanation: Before driving, be sure to check the tank's body for dents or cracks. You should also check around and under the vehicle for signs of leaks. It is a crime to carry gases or liquids in a leaking tank.

questions.question: To ensure that you do not slow down traffic when driving a large truck, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to pass another vehicle while driving uphill.
questions.answerC: Stay in the right lane whenever possible.
questions.explanation: If a heavy load prevents your vehicle from keeping up with the speed of other traffic, you should stay in the right lane.

questions.question: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check for all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Too much air pressure in your tires.
questions.answerB: Too little air pressure in your tires.
questions.answerC: A consistent name brand across all of your tires.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should verify that the air pressure is neither too low nor too high in any of your tires.

questions.question: A thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces is called:
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet. You should be very careful when temperatures are below freezing and the road looks wet.

questions.question: Which gas would cause concern due to a faulty exhaust system?
questions.explanation: A leaking exhaust system can introduce carbon monoxide, which is poisonous, into the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerA: Are not a cause for concern.
questions.explanation: The suspension system holds up a vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Defects in this system are extremely dangerous.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of distraction?
questions.explanation: Distractions that can affect safe driving can be classified as physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as talking with passenger), or both (such as talking on a hand-held phone).

questions.question: A loaded trailer with a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Gets better gas mileage than an unloaded trailer.
questions.answerC: Is usually more stable than an unloaded trailer.
questions.explanation: A trailer with a high center of gravity is at a greater risk of rolling over than a trailer with a low center of gravity.

questions.question: If there is a fire in your vehicle, you should not:
questions.answerA: Park in an area away from buildings, trees, brush, and other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Notify emergency services of your problem and your location.
questions.explanation: In the event of a vehicle fire, you should leave the road and stop in an open area. Do not pull into a service station as fuels at the service station could catch fire. Report the fire and your location to emergency services.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerC: Deal with it and drive at a safe speed.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of developing aggressive driving behavior, you should take measures to manage your stress. One strategy to do this is to simply take a deep breath and accept your circumstances if you realize you will be late to your destination.

questions.question: Compared to talking on a cell phone while driving, texting while driving is:
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is even more dangerous than speaking on a phone while driving. In addition to being mentally distracting, texting is also physically distracting.

questions.question: When entering a curve, you should:
questions.explanation: You should always slow down to a safe speed and shift into a lower gear before entering a curve.

questions.question: Of the following, which is the most slippery surface?
questions.explanation: Ice becomes wet when the weather is just warm enough to melt the ice slightly. Wet ice is much more slippery than ice that is not wet.

questions.question: A fatigued driver:
questions.answerB: Is usually more conscientious than a typical driver.
questions.answerC: May be slower to make critical decisions than a typical driver.
questions.explanation: Fatigued drivers are slower to see or react to hazards than drivers who are not fatigued. Drivers are impaired in their ability to make critical decisions when they are driving drowsy.

questions.question: What is brake lag?
questions.answerA: The time required for the brakes to work after the brake pedal is pressed
questions.answerB: The distance between the brake pedal and the floor
questions.answerC: The amount of air pressure used to stop the vehicle
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a warning sign of fatigue?
questions.explanation: Potential warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing, frequent blinking, or heavy eyelids; yawning repeatedly or rubbing your eyes; daydreaming; wandering or disconnected thoughts; trouble remembering the last few miles you've driven; missing exits or traffic signs; having trouble keeping your head up; drifting from your lane; following too closely; hitting a shoulder rumble strip; or feeling restless and irritable.

questions.question: When coming to a stop, the liquid in a tank may surge. This can:
questions.answerA: Cause the truck to stop too quickly.
questions.answerB: Cause the truck to be pushed forward.
questions.explanation: When liquid surges in a tank that is partially filled, the truck tends to be pushed in the direction of the wave. If a truck is being stopped on a slippery surface, the surge may push it forward into an intersection or another vehicle.

questions.question: When inspecting the windshield before a trip, a person should do all the following, except:
questions.answerA: Remove and sharpen the wiper blades.
questions.answerB: Check the windshield wipers for proper spring tension.
questions.answerC: Check the wiper blades for damage.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your windshield, you should look for cracks or other problems that could interfere with your ability to clearly see the road. The windshield wiper arms should be checked for proper spring tension. The wiper blades should be checked for damage, stiff rubber, and improper securement.

questions.question: To avoid a hazard:
questions.answerA: You should always steer to the left.
questions.answerB: You may be able to drive onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: You should steer sharply in one direction.
questions.explanation: In some emergencies, the best strategy for avoiding a hazard may be to drive onto the shoulder. Most shoulders are strong enough to support the weight of a large vehicle.

questions.question: What does an air compressor do in an air brake system?
questions.answerA: It pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: It moves air to the back of the truck.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks. The air compressor is controlled by the air compressor governor.

questions.question: During a trip, landing gear should be:
questions.explanation: Landing gear, or trailer supports, should always be completely raised before a vehicle is driven. Landing gear that is not entirely raised could catch on railroad tracks or other hazards on the roadway.

questions.question: Regrooved tires:
questions.answerA: Should not be used on any vehicle.
questions.answerB: Should not be used on the front of a bus.
questions.answerC: Should not be used on trucks hauling gravel.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are prohibited on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: If a tire fails, you should:
questions.explanation: Braking after a tire fails can result in a loss of control. Stay off your brakes, if possible, until your vehicle has slowed considerably.

questions.question: Brake linings should be:
questions.explanation: Brake linings should not be loose or soaked with oil or grease. They shouldn't be dangerously thin.

questions.question: If a truck is equipped, a trailer brake hand valve can be used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent the truck from rolling back when being started from a stop.
questions.explanation: If a tractor-trailer is so equipped, the trailer brake hand valve can be used to stop the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.

questions.question: Aggressive driving is:
questions.answerA: Operating a vehicle in a selfish or pushy manner.
questions.answerB: Operating a vehicle with a strong regard for other motorists’ safety.
questions.answerC: Operating a vehicle in the left lane.
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is the act of operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner and without regard for the rights or safety of other road users.

questions.question: When checking power steering hoses during a pre-trip inspection, you should look for:
questions.answerC: Extra hose pieces available for repairs.
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-trip inspection on a vehicle with power steering, be sure to check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. In particular, you should check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed by:
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed when traveling on surfaces that provide reduced traction. Reduce your speed by one-half or more when traveling on packed snow.

questions.question: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull over and figure out what's wrong.
questions.explanation: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should stop driving as soon as possible and try to figure out what is wrong. There could be an issue in your vehicle that could lead to engine failure and possibly a fire.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable if found during a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerB: Tread of 3/32 of an inch in the grooves of the front tires
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires, and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch on the other tires. Tires on the same vehicle should all be the same size.

questions.question: The use of a hand-held mobile device while driving is:
questions.answerB: Acceptable if weather conditions are clear.
questions.explanation: Using a hand-held mobile telephone while operating a CMV is both illegal and dangerous.

questions.question: On a slippery road, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Make turns as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: Under slippery conditions, you should drive slowly and smoothly. Make turns as gently as possible and do not pass other vehicles unless you have to.

questions.question: What is the best way to stop if your brakes fail while you are driving downhill?
questions.answerB: Let the vehicle slow down on its own.
questions.answerC: Let rumble strips slow your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail on a downgrade, you will need to quickly find something outside that can stop your vehicle. An escape ramp is the best option. If no escape ramp is available, use the least hazardous available option, such as driving into an open field or side road that flattens out or turns uphill.

questions.question: Black ice is:
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. The surface will look like a wet road. Always be alert to black ice if the road looks wet when the temperature is below freezing.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, you should begin by:
questions.answerA: Turning the steering wheel in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Turning the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerC: Turning the wheel as sharply as possible.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, begin by turning the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn. Once the trailer starts to turn, reverse the direction of the steering wheel to follow the trailer.

questions.question: When near a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: You should expect to hear every approaching train.
questions.answerB: You may not hear a train, even if one is approaching.
questions.answerC: You will hear two short blasts of a train's horn if a train is approaching.
questions.explanation: You should never assume that you will hear an approaching train. The train operator may fail to sound the horn, or the use of a train's horn may be prohibited in a specific area. Even if the train does sound its horn, noise from inside your own vehicle may prevent you from hearing the train until it is dangerously close.

questions.question: After two violations of any state law regarding hand-held mobile phone use:
questions.answerA: You will need to cancel your mobile phone service.
questions.answerC: You will be required to drive 10 mph under the posted speed limit for a period of time.
questions.explanation: If you are twice convicted of violating any state law regarding hand-held mobile phone use, your CDL will be disqualified. Consequences will become more severe with subsequent violations.

questions.question: Shortly after a tire has been changed, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop to make sure the lug nuts are still tight.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, you should stop a short while later to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated while driving a large vehicle, do all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: If you find yourself being tailgated by another driver, you should increase your following distance and avoid making quick moves. Increasing your speed may only result in the other driver continuing to tailgate you at a higher speed. Do not turn on your taillights or flash your brake lights at the other driver.

questions.question: When starting from a stop:
questions.answerA: A vehicle should shift to the right.
questions.answerB: A vehicle should be put into third gear.
questions.answerC: A vehicle should not roll back.
questions.explanation: To avoid hitting anything behind you, make sure that your vehicle does not roll back when you start from a complete stop.

questions.question: The more alcohol in the body:
questions.answerA: The quicker the liver will digest the alcohol.
questions.answerB: The less effect the alcohol will have on the individual.
questions.answerC: The longer it will take to remove the alcohol from the body.
questions.explanation: The body removes alcohol at a fixed rate. The more alcohol consumed, the longer it will take for the body to remove the alcohol from its system.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be applied.
questions.answerB: The parking brake should be applied.
questions.answerC: Brakes should not be applied if the vehicle is left out of gear.
questions.explanation: Parking brakes should be used whenever you park. If necessary, chock your wheels.

questions.question: What does the vehicle inspection report do?
questions.answerA: Inform the motor carrier about problems that may need fixing
questions.answerB: Ensure that the vehicle is inspected regularly
questions.answerC: Keep people accountable for inspecting the vehicle
questions.explanation: A vehicle inspection report keeps the carrier informed about any problems that need to be fixed.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact to better communicate with them.
questions.answerC: Not move out of their path of travel.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, it is most important to get out of their way, if possible. Do not make eye contact with the driver, as doing so could provoke them. Do not let them provoke you with their actions.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerB: Should be repaired, but not immediately.
questions.explanation: The suspension system performs the vital functions of holding up the vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Defects in the suspension are therefore extremely dangerous.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep grade, you switch into a lower gear:
questions.answerB: When you have already started the grade.
questions.answerC: As far down the grade as possible.
questions.explanation: You should shift your vehicle's transmission into a low gear before staring a downhill grade. Be prepared for gravity to increase your vehicle's speed when traveling downhill.

questions.question: When driving in winter, which of the following should receive extra attention in a pre-trip inspection?
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-trip inspection during the winter, you should pay extra attention to the coolant level and amount of antifreeze; the defrosting and heating equipment; the wiper blades and windshield washer; the tires and tire chains; the lights and reflectors; the windows and mirrors; the hand holds, steps, and deck plates; the radiator shuttles and winterfront; and exhaust system.

questions.question: When driving a bus with passengers, you should:
questions.answerA: Not engage in conversation with the passengers.
questions.answerB: Fuel the bus with the passengers on board.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of distraction, bus drivers should not engage in conversation with passengers. Avoid fueling a bus while passengers are on board. Do not tow or push a disabled bus with riders aboard the vehicle, unless it would be unsafe for the passengers to exit the bus at the location where it has stalled.

questions.question: Bridges usually freeze:
questions.answerA: Only once temperatures drop significantly below 32 degrees Fahrenheit.
questions.explanation: Bridges tend to freeze before other parts of the roadway. Be particularly careful on bridges when temperatures are close to the freezing point.

questions.question: If another driver is tailgating you, you should:
questions.answerC: Increase the distance between you and the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, you should increase the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead. This will reduce your need to make sudden moves, and will also allow the tailgater more room to pass you. Speeding up when being tailgated is not advised because it may result in the tailgater continuing to follow you closely at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: When traveling on a downgrade, your vehicle will:
questions.answerB: Travel at the same rate as on level roadway.
questions.explanation: Gravity causes a vehicle's speed to increase when traveling on a downgrade. Adjust your speed before reaching a downgrade.

questions.question: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed by:
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed when traveling on surfaces that provide reduced traction. Reduce your speed by one-half or more when traveling on packed snow.

questions.question: How should you brake if your vehicle's ABS is not working?
questions.answerA: Brake normally, as you will still have functioning brakes.
questions.answerC: Press the brake pedal down as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: Without a working Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), your vehicle will still have normal brake function. Continue to drive and brake as you normally would and have your ABS serviced as soon as possible.

questions.question: If you’re unfamiliar with the area in which you must back up, you should:
questions.answerA: Get out of your vehicle and walk around the area to become more familiar with it.
questions.answerB: Not use both side mirrors because it can be distracting.
